content.description: Fun vertical climbing leads to a pumpy crux pulling around the lip of the roof just below the chains.
content.location: From the descent trail, head past the first set of routes you encounter and then further past the waterfall until you find the next group of routes on the other side. This climbs just to the left of the "egyptian roof" (large upside down staircase).

content.description:
Climb the face using lots of good edges to reach the roof. Keep lots of tension to make it around the lip, and then paddle up increasingly good jugs to a final mantle boulder problem on side pull jugs below the chains.

 Put your PJ's on and get some jammies to make this thing pretty soft for the grade.

 This route likely stays dry in the rain and seepage.
content.location: From the descent, hike past the water fall. First route right of the egyptians roof and climbs.

content.description:
This route has a tricky crux and cool moves but is marred by some low rock quality (even for the canyon). Climb the reachy face to the jug shelves behind the tree and below the roof. Pull gingerly over there, those are coming off sometime. Figure out the eponymous boulder problem to gain the face above the roof (think Karate Kid) and then get what you can back by the bolt. Traverse right and then left to increasingly good jugs above a run out and then on to the chains.

 This route likely stays dry in the rain and seepage.
content.protection: 7 bolts + chains. There's a chain permadraw above the roof and a sling leaver draw at the end of the roof.
content.location: To the right of Steel Magnolias.

content.description: Same start as Egyptian Orgasm, but splits right after first bolt. Conjure up creative beta at first roof but save a little for a crimpy face above.
Intro face fluff leads to a interesting roof pull and pumpy face to the final roof. Individual moves are not too challenging for a 12 but the limited rests makes this one a pump factory.
content.location: One bolt line right of welcome to little river. The first bolt of this climb is shared with Egyptian Steel (12d).

content.description:
Brandnewbia, branubia, brandnoobia... however you spell it. This wall has some great routes but suffers from some serious seepage and lack luster rock quality in places. It's still worth a visit though, especially if you're trying to avoid the crowds on a nice day.

 Most climbs here will not be climbable after a heavy rain fall, but a few are protected under rock shelters. Wait a few days after a rain storm to let it dry out.

 Wall gets lots of sun, so maybe go on a cooler day.
